ratings.question_text: Which of the following best describes your mode of learning in this course?
options: virtual seminar or other discussion format
in-person seminar or other discussion format

ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of <u>intellectual challenge</u> of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the <u>workload</u> of this course was:

narratives.question_text: Please list any other mode(s) of learning, including any combination or variation of the above options.
comments: We had the first two lectures virtual as well as the last lecture, but the remainder were in person meetings of the ensemble
3 weeks were online zoom seminar, the rest in-person rehearsal
Our class held weekly met in-person meetings where we played gamelan together, while masked and distanced. In total, we had three or four virtual meetings in which we held discussions.
We had 3 live virtual seminars (2 in the beginning and 1 at the end of the semester). All other weekly meetings were in-person rehearsals with the gamelan instruments.

narratives.question_text:
What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: I learned about the culture of Javanese Gamelan as well as how to play in the ensemble, playing various pieces on various instruments
I learned the basics of gamelan play across four instruments along with the rich history of Javanese gamelan ensemble.
I became familiar with the cultural context of Central Javanese gamelan and learned to play the main categories of instruments in the Yale gamelan ensemble.

I learned how to play various instruments in the gamelan ensemble, as well as how to listen and coordinate my playing with other members of the ensemble in order to play cohesively. I also learned about the cultural and historical context surrounding the gamelan in Central Java.

narratives.question_text:
What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: The strengths of this course are the effective execution of an in person course in which I was able to learn gamelan, while utilizing social distancing practices. Additionally, the assessments and virtual lectures were very effective in providing a background and context to the musical practice we were engaging in as an emsemble

This course really struggled in this pandemic semester. Any cultural learning from the virtual seminar meeting was never mentioned outside of zoom, and rehearsals were awkward with a "learn by doing" mindset that needed more clear instruction. Assignments seemed out of sync with the rest of the course, which seemed to be almost entirely focused on in-rehearsal participation. They were graded kind of harshly by the professor who was not actually instructing us in class and did not seem to reflect the chill attitude of rehearsal. Communication about upcoming assignments was also difficult, with surprise midterms and final projects we didn't know about until they were happening. Rehearsals were also frustrating, as I believe many students would have benefited from basic music skills instruction, which we never got. Grading was sometimes harsh and inconsistent, which was confusing, since the class seemed like it was supposed to be a very laid-back environment.

This is a great course. The professors are extremely knowledgable, kind and enthusiastic about what they do. The one thing I would improve upon is more flexibility. Some students struggled playing certain instruments, and I wish that students had the ability to swap in these cases so that the overall ensemble performance could be improved.

I really liked the lectures with Maho and the readings that accompanied them, and I was so grateful for the chance to work with Mas Dar for our in person rehearsals. The long rehearsal time on Fridays was intensely challenging for the mind and the arms, especially when we played a 10+ minute piece, stopped for 20 seconds, and then did it twice more. When we made mistakes at the end of the piece or at a tempo change, more often than not, we would start the piece from the beginning, take every repeat (sometimes taking a repeat four times, tiring our arms without addressing the reason we stopped) , and not play the part where we made the mistake for multiple minutes. I wish we had used our rehearsal time to target specific parts of the pieces that had the most issues. I might not have struggled playing the last measure of certain pieces if we'd just played the last 20 seconds instead of the whole thing repeatedly, and it might have helped the long rehearsal time feel less monotonous. Overall, I am grateful I took this course, but sometimes the rehearsal practices contributed to my repeated exhaustion by 3:25.

This class is an incredibly fun and immersive experience. Mas Dar was an amazing instructor for our in-person rehearsals; he always listened to carefully to each student's playing and gave constructive feedback. It was also inspiring to hear him talk about his experiences playing gamelan in Java. For our seminar discussions, Maho was a wonderful instructor who clearly cares a lot about her students. I learned a ton about cultural practices surrounding the gamelan, and it definitely has piqued my interest in a musical tradition that I knew very little about beforehand.

narratives.question_text: Among the practices in this course geared toward learning during the COVID-19 pandemic, which succeeded and which could be improved? Please comment on course practices that allowed for virtual engagement. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: The course was very successful especially given the COVID-19 pandemic. Having in person rehearsal once a week for 2 hours as opposed to split into two shorter class sessions was a little difficult, but given the circumstances completely understandable.

I thought the COVID-19 practices for the in-person rehearsals were well-planned and safe. All of the instruments were spread out according to social distancing policies, and all students wore gloves and masks at all times.

narratives.question_text:
Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: I would definitely recommend this course to another student. It was a great experience that challenged me and exposed me to Gamelan, an art that I hope  and plan to continue to interact with in the future.

I would recommend this in another semester maybe. I was never comfortable or knew quite what was expected of me, and communication between Mas Dar, who saw only in-person instruction, and Maho, who ran everything on canvas and zoom, was difficult and intimidating to try to give feedback about when things didn't seem to line up because they're married.
Yes!
I would absolutely recommend this course. It's very fun and rewarding to learn gamelan and teaches you unexpected lessons that you may otherwise not be taught in a classroom.

Yes, I would absolutely recommend this course to anyone interested in learning a new instrument and/or a cultural practice. I would especially encourage graduating seniors to take this class, since it is a unique and rewarding experience compared to most "normal" classes at Yale.
